newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore sets plan to end telecom monopoly.
newsitem.headline: Singapore sets plan to end telecom monopoly.

text.p: Singapore announced its plans on Monday for ending Singapore Telecommunications Ltd's (SingTel) monopoly by allowing at least one other operator into the business.

Communications Minister Mah Bow Tan said a two-stage tender process would decide who would be allowed to compete against SingTel on basic telecommunications services, including local and international phone calls, from 1 April, 2000.
He said the licences to be awarded would also include services for voice telephony, lease circuits, public switched message and data services.
Mah said the first stage of the process would be a pre-qualification exercise held on March 1 1997. The second, for short listed candidates, would be in September 1997.

"The results of the main tender are expected to be announced in mid-1998. The successful licensee or licensees will have around 18 months before the licence commencement date of April 1 2000 to build, roll out and test their networks and services," he said.
The Singapore government had said in May it would bring forward the opening of its basic telecommunication services to April 2000 from its original date of 2007.
It said then that SingTel would be paid compensation of S$1.5 billion by March 1997.
SingTel was begun as a state enterprise, then turned into a public corporation three years ago and all Singaporean adults were offered shares in it at a discount.
The government's investment company, Temasek, still holds more than 80 percent of the shares.
Mah made the announcement at the signing ceremony for the formation of the Singapore One Infrastructure Consortium.
The consortium, led by the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (TAS), is being formed to bring wide-spread multi-media services and applications to Singapore.
